X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=197251447; y=PpAK987ZGSqQ8ltC-w5jYCvqJyWUBV8syJ3viefAZQ3dMw

>Has anybody converted the contents of the NEATWIN2.ZIP, located in the 
>Files area, to MSVC++ 6.0 or .NET? I'm particularly interested 
>in "Darren's Program Experiment" contained therein.

It's a while since I uploaded that file, and the experiment you 
mention was a little disappointing in practice.

The purpose was to use NEAT to evolve networks which would output 
programs in a simple stack-based language to generate given sequences 
of numbers. You may be wondering: why make the network generate a 
program to do it rather than have the network generate the sequences 
directly? Mainly because it's really hard to reverse-engineer the 
algorithms networks are using and understand how they're working, and 
it would be more practical in some ways to evolve routines in a form 
closer to conventional programming languages.

The real difficulty comes down to finding a good representation of a 
program which the network can output. The Program Experiment tried to 
have the network build up the program instruction by instruction, able 
to move back and forth through the list to change instructions as 
needed. This was, in some ways, the inverse of the roving eye method 
for inputs, and I had hoped it would mean a program-generator could be 
evolved incrementally. The main problem was that there was such a huge 
jump in complexity required between a simple, useless program which 
just returned the average of the sequence (or some other simple 
output, such as a counter) and a meaningful one which actually 
calculated a value.

Therefore, a better representation would have to be found where these 
jumps would be minimised. One possibility which did occur would be to 
make the transformations the network could apply to the list of 
instructions more sophisticated, a bit like the ones ADATE applies to 
programs it evolves.

At any rate, I now use SharpNeat (which naturally works quite well 
under VS.NET!) although I haven't recreated anything like the Program 
Experiment yet, simply because I haven't thought of a better way of 
doing it.

--Darren
